page.title: 04RAILWAY HISTORY IN GLENFIELD
page.content: The{railway tunnel in Glenfield}was built in 1832 as a part of the {Leicester and Swannington Railway, engineered by George Stephenson and his son Robert. At that time it was the longest railway tunnel in the world. The railway was built to bring coal and stone to Leicester. The station was sited where Stephensons Court stands to_day. The first steam engine on the line was called the Comet. On its opening run it hit its chimney on the roof of the tunnel showering the passengers with smuts. After the railway was closed to traffic in 1964, the track was lifted, the tunnel was sold to Leicester City Council for Â£5 and the level crossing keepers cottage was knocked down. The Glenfield end of the tunnel is still there and the track of the line behind Station Rd can be walked.
